content: The Small Business Defense Conversion Guaranteed Loan Act of 1994 authorizes certain guarantees. Section 20 of the Small Business Act is amended by striking and inserting appropriate language, redesigning subsections, and inserting paragraphs 1 and 2. The Administration is authorized to make up to $4,000,000,000 in loans on a guaranteed basis, as per Section 7(a)(21), with the amount remaining available until expended. The Administration is authorized to make loans up to $4,000,000,000 on a guaranteed basis, in accordance with subsections A and B, by striking certain sections and inserting new paragraphs. The text chunk discusses the reorganization of subsections and paragraphs in accordance with Section 7 of the loan authorization. The Small Business Act is amended by striking and inserting on a guaranteed basis under the SEC. 4, reaching additional small business concerns. Section 7(a)(21)(A)(i) of the Small Business Act is amended by reducing revenues of small businesses due to a decrease in economic activity within the community they operate in. The reduction in economic activity directly impacts small businesses' revenues. The Small Business Defense Conversion Assistance Act of 1994 includes provisions for a Defense Conversion Loan Guarantee Program and various Small Business Administration authorities. The Small Business Defense Conversion Assistance Act of 1994 includes provisions for a Defense Conversion Loan Guarantee Program under Title I. The Small Business Act is amended to authorize the Administration to make up to $4 billion in guaranteed loans under section 7(a)(21). The Small Business Act is amended to authorize the Administration to make up to $4 billion in guaranteed loans under section 7(a)(21) without fiscal year limitation. The Small Business Act is amended to authorize the Administration to make up to $4 billion in guaranteed loans under section 7(a)(21) without fiscal year limitation. The Administration is authorized to make loans on a guaranteed basis, with the amount not exceeding $4 billion, and to remain available without fiscal year limitation. SEC. 102 amends the Small Business Act to clarify loans made on a guaranteed basis. SEC. 103 expands eligibility for small businesses facing revenue reductions due to economic downturns. SEC. 104 establishes separate appropriations requirements. SEC. 104 amends the Small Business Act to require separate appropriations for loans authorized under a specific paragraph. Authorization of appropriations for defense conversion assistance program is amended by adding $15,000,000 for each of fiscal years 1995, 1996, and 1997 to carry out subsection (c)(3)(G). The Small Business Administration requires a 50 percent matching amount from sources other than the Federal Government for grants to Small Business Development Centers. Additionally, funds are allocated to Small Business Development Centers under the Small Business Act. Funds allocated to Small Business Development Centers under the Small Business Act are exempt from being included in the calculation of Administration assistance. Amendments to the Small Business Act specify exceptions regarding the calculation of assistance amounts. SEC. 202. JOB CREATION AND COMMUNITY BENEFIT. Section 7(a)(21) of the Small Business Act is amended to prioritize job creation and community benefit in assistance projects, focusing on creating new jobs for individuals affected by defense expenditure reductions or preventing job losses in small businesses. The Small Business Act is amended to prioritize job creation and community benefit in assistance projects for small businesses impacted by defense expenditure reductions. SEC. 203. Development Company Loan Program reauthorization increases funding from $1.2 billion to $1.5 billion. SEC. 204. Disaster Loan Temporary Personnel extends personnel term from six months to 12 months. The bill authorizes funding for small business defense conversion programs and the Development Company Loan Program of the Small Business Administration.
